techniques.name: Downstroke Power Chords
techniques.description: Essential AC/DC technique using exclusively downstrokes for power chords to achieve the characteristic attack and sustain

notes: Use exclusively downstrokes for all power chord changes
Maintain consistent attack strength across all strokes
Slight palm edge contact with bridge for control
Clean attack without heavy palm muting
sequence: Position picking hand over bridge area
Use wrist motion for downstroke attack
Follow through completely on each stroke
tips: Practice slowly to build stamina and consistency
Focus on the low E and A strings for power chord foundation
Keep unused strings slightly muted to avoid noise
Build up speed gradually to maintain clean attack

techniques.name: I-♭VII-IV Progression
techniques.description: Classic rock progression using the characteristic ♭VII chord (D major in key of E) that defines the AC/DC sound

notes: The ♭VII chord creates the classic rock sound
Simple but effective harmonic movement
Foundation for countless AC/DC songs
Easy to learn but requires precise timing
sequence: Resolve through A5 (IV) back to E5 (I)
tips: Practice chord changes slowly at first
Focus on clean transitions between power chords
Use minimal finger movement between changes
Keep the same picking hand rhythm throughout
details.progression: I - ♭VII - IV - I in E Major

techniques.name: Simple Lead Lines
techniques.description: Pentatonic-based melodic phrases that complement the rhythm guitar without overcomplicating the arrangement

notes: Based on E minor pentatonic scale
Uses whole-step bends for expression
Sparse placement for maximum impact
Complements rather than competes with rhythm
sequence: Position in 12th fret area for lead tones
Execute whole-step bends on high B string
Return to rhythm playing between phrases
tips: Focus on tone quality over complexity
Practice bends to reach exact pitch
Listen to original for phrase placement

sections.name: Main Riff
sections.description: The iconic opening riff that establishes the song's energy and showcases the I-♭VII-IV-I progression
notes: Four quarter notes per chord
All downstrokes with consistent attack
Clean power chord voicings
Establishes the song's driving rhythm

sections.name: Verse
sections.description: Verse section with simple I-IV movement providing space for lead guitar phrases
notes: Simplified chord progression for vocal space
Lead guitar adds melodic elements over rhythm
Maintains downstroke consistency
Creates dynamic contrast with main riff

sections.name: Chorus
sections.description: Return of the main riff with full intensity and the characteristic I-♭VII-IV-I progression
notes: Identical to main riff with full band intensity
Emphasizes the ♭VII chord tension and release
Peak energy section of the song
Signature AC/DC progression showcased

sections.name: Bridge
sections.description: Bridge section with descending power chord movement creating tension before return to main theme
notes: Descending sequence builds tension
Higher register power chords for contrast
Leads back to familiar E5 resolution
Creates dynamic lift before final choruses

guitar.pickup: Humbuckers for thick, sustained power chord tone

effects.other: No effects pedals - pure guitar and amp tone

beginner.focus: Learn the basic power chord shapes and simple chord changes
steps: Master E5, A5, and D5 power chord shapes
Learn the main riff chord progression

intermediate.focus: Develop consistent downstroke technique and rhythm precision
steps: Work on dynamic control between sections

advanced.focus: Add lead guitar elements and perfect tone reproduction

commonMistakes: Using upstrokes instead of consistent downstrokes
Playing too fast initially without building stamina
practiceRoutine: Warm up with simple E5 downstrokes for 5 minutes
Build tempo gradually from 60 BPM to 93 BPM
Work on stamina with extended downstroke practice
metronomeWork: Start at 60 BPM with simple downstrokes
Work on maintaining consistent timing throughout song

sameArtist.title: Highway to Hell
sameArtist.similarity: Similar downstroke technique and power chord approach

sameArtist.title: Thunderstruck
sameArtist.similarity: More complex but uses same fundamental AC/DC techniques

similarTechniques.title: You Shook Me All Night Long
similarTechniques.similarity: Similar chord progressions and downstroke technique
